questions.question: Describe the initiatives taken under the 'Operation Blackboard' scheme.
questions.answer: In 1988, the central government initiated Operation Blackboard to improve primary education standards. Funds were provided to fulfill minimum needs such as at least two proper classrooms, toilets, one female teacher among two, a blackboard, maps, laboratory apparatus, a library, and sports equipment. In 1994, the scheme expanded to include additional classrooms and teachers for schools with over 100 students, prioritizing girls' schools and rural areas.

questions.question: Explain the role and functions of the NCERT.
questions.answer: The National Council of Educational Research and Training (NCERT) was established in 1961 to assist the Central Government in school education policies. Its responsibilities include educational research and development, training, extension programmes, and restructuring school curricula and textbooks. It plays a central role in designing curricula with the CBSE and provides guidance to state governments. It also develops teacher handbooks and conducts national-level talent search examinations.

questions.question: Discuss the establishment and impact of the Indira Gandhi National Open University (IGNOU).
questions.answer: IGNOU was established in 1985 to bring education to every household, following a 1970 UNESCO seminar on Open Universities. Based on the P. Parthasarathy committee's recommendations, it was named after Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. IGNOU offers education with flexible eligibility criteria, making it accessible to those who missed formal college. It launched audio-visual distance education in 1990 and operates over 1000 curricula through training centers in India and abroad.

questions.question: What are the contributions of the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR) to India?
questions.answer: Established in 1950, CSIR promotes scientific research in physics, chemistry, pharmaceuticals, and food processing. Its achievements include making indelible election ink, medicines for malaria and tuberculosis, water purification technology, and reducing bamboo production time. CSIR pioneered DNA fingerprinting in India, conducted genetic studies on Andaman Adivasis, and developed earthquake warning systems. It also played a role in neem pesticides and turmeric patents.

questions.question: Elaborate on the development of engineering education in India post-independence, focusing on IITs.
questions.answer: To meet the country's need for advanced engineering education, the first Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) was set up at Kharagpur in 1951. Engineering colleges in Powai, Chennai, Kanpur, and New Delhi were converted into IITs with help from Russia, America, Germany, and UNESCO. These institutes were granted deemed university status to offer BTech and MTech courses. Despite facing a 'Brain Drain' in the 70s and 80s, IITs expanded with new campuses in Guwahati (1994) and Roorkee (2001).

questions.question: Write a note on the Indian Institute of Management (IIM).
questions.answer: As high-quality engineers graduated from IITs, the need for skilled managers arose. The Central and Gujarat governments started the first IIM in Ahmedabad with help from Harvard Business School. Other IIMs were later set up in Kolkata, Bengaluru, Lucknow, Kozhikode, Indore, and Shillong to provide top-tier management education.

questions.question: Explain the significance of the Kothari Commission.
questions.answer: Appointed in 1964 under Dr. D. S. Kothari, the commission recommended the 10+2+3 pattern for secondary, higher secondary, and university education, implemented in 1972. It suggested a uniform national system, inclusion of mother tongue, Hindi, and English, and emphasized continuing and adult education. It also recommended increased budget provisions for neglected sections like Scheduled Castes and Tribes.

questions.question: Describe the progress in medical research in India post-independence.
questions.answer: The Indian Council for Medical Research (ICMR) was established in 1949 to guide and support research. Twenty-six centers were started for research on various diseases, helping control tuberculosis and leprosy. The All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) was set up for advanced education and research, providing treatment at nominal rates. Research in cancer, Ayurveda, and other fields also progressed significantly.
